Quantum mechanics is a highly successful theory that has been extremely influential in physics and mathematics. It has been extremely successful in part because it has been shown to be equivalent to a certain type of generalization of ordinary mathematics, namely, a certain type of mathematical structure called a Hilbert space. However, the mathematical structure of Hilbert space is not fully understood. This paper provides a categorical approach to the mathematical structure of Hilbert space. The approach is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. The approach is based on a set of axioms that are shown to be equivalent to the existing analytical structure. The approach provides a foundation for quantum theory that is free of the need for an axiom of choice.

The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. We also show that myxozoans are among the most reduced animals in terms of genome size and gene content. Our findings suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. This work also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of the Myxozoa and other parasitic groups. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The host immune response is a key factor in the control of SARS-CoV-2 infection. IFN signaling is a major component of the host immune response against viruses. However, some viruses have evolved strategies to evade IFN signaling. Here, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response. This knowledge will be useful to design new strategies to control the COVID-19 pandemic. Copyright © 2021. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will increase the variability of global crop yields. This study quantifies the magnitude of this increase and its consequences for global food security. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Herbivory is a major driver of ecosystem function and biodiversity. However, the extent to which different herbivore species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in plant consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivore species in semiarid African savanna. We found that even closely related species differed in their plant consumption, and that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest dietary overlap. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Our findings highlight the importance of species-level identification in understanding the role of herbivory in ecosystems. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months. Finally, many businesses expect the CARES Act to be difficult to access.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous and growing environmental problem. The global distribution and the fate of this pollution are still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of the plastic debris, which points at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. Copyright © 2015. The origin of the solar system is still a matter of debate. The most widely accepted scenario is that the solar system formed from the aggregation of planetesimals. The age of the solar system is estimated to be 4.57 Ga. However, the age of the oldest planetesimals is unknown. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are in agreement with the formation of the solar system at 4.57 Ga. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This will challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all organisms. In placental mammals, the mother’s ability to reproduce is limited by her own metabolic power. This is because the mother must provide all of the energy required to support the developing offspring. We show that the ability to provide energy to the offspring is a strong determinant of reproductive output. This is true for all forms of external energy supplementation, including domestication and all forms of allocare. The greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This may have important implications for the evolution of placental mammals and their ability to colonize new environments. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic approach for MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept of the potential of VX-765 to limit α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in synucleinopathy models. This study also highlights the potential of VX-765 to be used in clinical trials in patients with synucleinopathies. This study opens the way to further investigations to assess the potential of VX-765 in patients with MSA. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

It controls vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. To control each function, the endothelium processes endlessly arriving requests from multiple sources using separate clusters of cells specialized to detect specific stimuli. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through a common format, allowing researchers to easily combine and analyze them. The data are also available in a revision-tracking format, allowing researchers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The COVIDcast API is available at no cost and is open source.

Anxiety is a common psychiatric disorder that is associated with a variety of social impairments. However, the underlying mechanisms remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter exhibit reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that this low mitochondrial capacity is a consequence of a reduced ATP and increased reactive oxygen species production. Pharmacological approaches indicate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is a causal consequence of reduced mitochondrial function. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern is regulated by the transcription factor BCL11A. In this study, we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1 is expressed in human erythroid tissues and is down-regulated during fetal development. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of BCL11A and the consequent reprogramming of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This may have implications for the understanding of hemoglobinopathies and the potential for therapeutic approaches to correct the hemoglobin expression pattern. Copyright © 2015. Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy and succumb to the disease. Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the development of resistance to therapy is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis confers cancer cells resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer patients with PI3K-mutated or PTEN-defective tumors. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. The underlying molecular mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are not fully understood. Here, we show that voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs) activate store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of plasma membrane ORAI. Our findings may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies for heart failure. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for forest conservation in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring and adaptive management, and provided a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but the policy has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older forest bird populations. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of early-seral bird populations, but the area of early-seral ecosystems has increased. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our results demonstrate the potential of computational drug design for the discovery of new antibiotics. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and other countries. This study shows that this practice can have negative effects on sleep. Participants who read an electronic book on a light-emitting device took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation. Its function is essential for the development of immunological tolerance, but its specific role in different autoimmune diseases remains to be determined. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 deletion induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of Treg cells, but this was not sufficient to prevent the development of autoimmunity. Moreover, CTLA-4 deletion had opposing effects on different autoimmune models. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance. Thus, CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its specific role in different autoimmune diseases remains to be determined. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes for 521 species. Our analyses resolved controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, which allowed beetles to become the most diverse group of animals. Our results suggest that these genes were key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. This resulted in multiple adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores, including leaf miners and wood borers, that led to the current diversity of beetles. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity and the origin of plant cell wall digestion. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines and therapies. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning approach to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We applied this approach to a human antibody, P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our approach identified CDR changes that improved the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work provides a promising approach for antibody optimization and its application to the development of new therapeutics. Copyright © 2022. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is the process by which cultural traits spread through a population and become more common over time. The extent to which larger populations enhance CCE is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the evolution of CCE may be more complex than previously thought. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE is a lipid-binding protein that is expressed in many cell types, including astrocytes. APOE is also a major component of senescent synapses, which are highly vulnerable to complement-mediated neurotoxicity. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of complement component C1q in senescent synapses. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is supported by the fact that APOE4 knock-in mice have increased complement-mediated neurotoxicity. These studies also suggest that APOE may be a therapeutic target for AD. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest and densest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We demonstrate that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. It is expected to be helpful for understanding the origin of the inner core and the evolution of the core–mantle boundary. Marijuana legalization debates highlight the need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. We investigated the effects of marijuana on brain DA reactivity in healthy controls and marijuana abusers. Compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly blunted responses to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers had reduced decreases in striatal dopamine D2 receptor availability (reflecting DA increases) when challenged with MP. In ventral striatum (key brain reward region), MP-induced reductions in DVs and BPND (reflecting DA increases) were inversely correlated with scores of negative emotionality, which were significantly higher for marijuana abusers than controls. In marijuana abusers, DA responses in ventral striatum were also inversely correlated with addiction severity and craving. The attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal DVs, are consistent with decreased brain reactivity to the DA stimulation in marijuana abusers that might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on brain function and for developing effective treatments for marijuana abuse. Copyright © 2015. Language is a uniquely human ability, and understanding its neural basis is a major goal of cognitive neuroscience. Here, we show that the most accurate artificial neural networks for predicting upcoming words in natural language processing also predict the neural responses to sentences in the human brain. This suggests that the mechanisms that drive language comprehension are predictive in nature. We also find that model architecture is strongly associated with neural fit. These results provide computational evidence for the predictive nature of language comprehension in the human brain. They also suggest that predictive processing may be a general mechanism for higher-order cognition.

Deep learning has achieved unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear why deep learning works and how to design stable deep learning algorithms. We address this issue by studying the relationship between stability and approximation properties of neural networks. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a neural network. This provides a classification theory of stability and approximation properties of neural networks. Our results also suggest that deep learning is a universal method for solving optimization problems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. The latter is often attributed to a classic experiment published 45 years prior to the first case of COVID-19. This article discusses the flaws in the experiment’s design and its consequences for the interpretation of the results. It concludes with a discussion of the dangers of uncritically accepting research findings as “Lore” and the need to be more critical of the research we read.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a Mexican patient with leprosy and found that it contained a new species, which we named Mycobacterium lepromatosis. We also found that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy and may have implications for the development of new therapeutics. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Entanglement and entropy are central concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also key ingredients in the description of the emergence of thermodynamics. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nontrivial problem, which has so far been studied only for noninteracting systems. We show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the interacting system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a highly nontrivial task. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors. We developed a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is the only one currently in clinical development. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro and can grow robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is highly protective in hamsters and can be used for mass vaccination. This vaccine has the potential to be used in a large-scale vaccination program. Copyright © 2021. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a better understanding of the history of plague and its vectors. It may also be relevant for the current COVID-19 pandemic. Copyright © 2020. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of animals. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only associated with the evolution of brain size but also with the number of neurons. This study provides a more comprehensive understanding of the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. It also provides a more accurate picture of the evolutionary paths leading to high cognitive power.

Mitochondrial HSP90 (TRAP1) is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, making their utility as probes of TRAP1-specific function questionable. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. Global warming and biodiversity loss are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we do? We conducted a large-scale study to understand how people feel connected to others. We found that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of felt connection. Language processing involves the ability to integrate and hold information in working memory. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. We study the dynamics of a chemical network that is exposed to a strong thermodynamic forcing. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia by 33%. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of sex differences in animals. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In contrast, in many fish, birds, and insects, sex is determined by multiple interacting alleles, which can result in more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Siphonophores are pelagic cnidarians that use specialized tentacles armed with nematocysts to capture prey. Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change and is associated with a range of negative impacts on people’s livelihoods and health. However, little is known about the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets. We show that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruit and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. Our findings also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Ltd.

Modern agriculture is based on the use of farm machinery that has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
